Our aims are to process as many existing outstanding issues/pull requests as possible and implement good practises for the future of the engine, such as automatic compile/unit testing of pull requests, as well as managing the different release files.

data.body: Required for CI server #677.

data.title: Make more object types mountable
data.body:
Currently `Item` cannot be mounted to other objects. AFAIR `StaticShape` doesn't mount either. We should review the mounting functionality of all `ShapeBase` derivatives and decide whether they should be mountable.

| Class | Does it mount? | Should it? | Implemented |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| `Item` | No | Yes | **No** |
| `Player` | Yes | Yes | Yes |
| `StaticShape` | Yes | Yes | Yes |
| `RigidShape` and friends | No | Yes | **No** |
| `Camera` and `PathCamera` |  |  |  |
| `Vehicle` and friends |  |  |  |
| `TSStatic` |  | Yes |  |

data.title: PostEffect Doesn't clear out constants on shader reload
data.body:
In the PostEffect class, if you cause the shader to be updated (e.g. by changing a macro via `setShaderMacro()` or `reload()`), the shader will be cleared in [checkRequirements](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/development/Engine/source/postFx/postEffect.cpp#L1389), but the shader constant buffer (mShaderConsts) and the constants list (mEffectConsts) will not be updated to point to the new shader.

This causes problems in the OpenGL renderer as the constant buffer state becomes out of sync with the shader state. e.g. the render target size may be 0,0 since it still thinks the size is 1024,1024. The Direct3D renderer doesn't appear to be affected by this, possibly because it updates using ranges rather than on a per-constant basis.

data.title: Instancing used excessively for single models
data.body:
In https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/d5beea41c882a1ec5454813ee9d4ffbb2345ff1d/Engine/source/ts/tsMesh.cpp#L244 a mesh will be drawn using an instancing material hook if it has less than 200 vertices in it. However this is not too optimal in all cases as for instance you might have several different models with < 200 verts in them with no commonality between them.

Drawing a single model with instancing is not a particularly good use of rendering time, especially in OpenGL as the renderer needs to stuff the model position in another vertex buffer, as opposed to just setting the uniform modelview.

Thoughts anyone? Personally I would have thought specifying this elsewhere like in the material itself would make more sense.

[BeamNG](http://www.beamng.com) has offered [CI servers to test Torque3D](http://t3dci.org).

Todo:

data.title: Fix dedicated Linux build.

data.title: Fix assertfatal/TORQUE_UNUSED release performance
data.body:
Fix AssertFatal/TORQUE_UNUSED are not optimized on release build causing performance problems.

http://cnicholson.net/2009/02/stupid-c-tricks-adventures-in-assert/

> "Both gcc and MSVC are smart enough to optimize out the evaluation of x, but only if they can determine if  there are no side effects associated with the evaluation.  Unfortunately, this can only be done if the body of x is known entirely to the compiler.  If x is a function call to another module MSVC can still make it go away with Link-Time Code Generation (via cross-module inlining), but poor gcc is dead in the water and emits the call.  Either way, weâ€™re relying on compiler and linker optimizations to make this code go away."

data.body:
```
void _StringTable::resize(const U32 _newSize)
{   
   ...
   temp->next = buckets[key % newSize]; // possible 0 division
   buckets[key % newSize] = temp; // possible 0 division
}
```

data.title: Add send queue to TCPObject

milestone.description: This version will focus on processing two of the major outstanding pull requests, James Urquhart's [TorqueScript interpreter improvements](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/81) and Tim Condon's [GUI additions](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/545). Along with that we'll be bringing in lots of other TS-related enhancements, adding unit tests for TS to make sure we don't break your games, and processing even more of the outstanding issue list.

data.body:
Implements a fix for issue #655 by adding a simple send queue to TCPObject. This also adds a SimpleDataQueue class to the engine (let me know if I somehow missed an already-existing streaming queued buffer class!).

All connected TCPObject instances are processed in the run loop to ensure all data has been sent. The send queue is iterated until either the queue is empty or the TCP layer stops sending bytes through.

Due to the varying mysterious nature of send buffers in TCP implementations it is advised that this code is tested simulating a pretty bad connection to ensure the buffer is actually made use of. In most cases the code will at least act like the old send() as a call to send the data is issued immediately.

data.title: Problem with dIsSpace with UTF8 text
data.body:
If you attempt to use dIsspace on UTF8 text which uses high ranged unicode characters (e.g. japanese text), you may get an assert in a DEBUG build on windows due to the character value being out of range for ASCII. This prevents such text from being passed to several functions making it slightly impractical to use international text in Torque3D, at least in windows.

I should also note that technically calling dIsspace on a UTF8 character is not quite correct as there are several space characters in unicode which don't fit into a single UTF8 character.

Affected functions:
- TrimFirstWord
- CodeBlock::exec (OP_ITER)
- isspace ConsoleFunction
- sParseList
- sGetArgNameAndType
- Namespace::Entry::getDocString
- parseFunctionArgumentNames
- GFont::wrapString
- GFXGLShader::_handleIncludes
- GuiTextEditCtrl::findPrevWord
- String::trim
- String::GetTrailingNumber
- nat_isspace
- SplitSequencePathAndName

data.title: Missing parameter in FixedSizeVector
data.body:
https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/development/Engine/source/core/util/tFixedSizeVector.h#L60

mArray[ 6 ]; is not assigned to "g", for all of the overloads.

data.title: TCPObject send does not send all data
data.body:
If you call send on a TCPObject, it might not send all the data depending on how full the OS's TCP send buffer is. This most commonly happens when you attempt to send large amounts of data through the object, e.g. file data.

Ideally Net::send should have an optional parameter to return the number of bytes sent. Also TCPObject itself needs a send buffer.

data.title: GuiBitmapButtonControl hangs if it can't find a bitmap or a default
data.body: In `GuiBitmapButtonControl::setBitmap`, if the given bitmap is not found, the function recurses into itself, trying to use `GFXTextureManager::getUnavailableTexturePath()` instead of the desired bitmap. If _this_ can't be found, it becomes an infinite loop. Probably shouldn't call this a bug, but it would be nice if we could recover from this situation gracefully rather than by hanging. I imagine similar logic is used elsewhere, too.

data.title: Wrapped decals with High Clipping angle distort UVs
data.body:
http://i.imgur.com/DEoOeHR.jpg

Not entirely sure where to start looking into this one, aside from a vague potential relation to https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/master/Engine/source/T3D/decal/decalManager.cpp#L351 on down. I can say the alterations to quadTransforms.cpp in https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/issues/201 had no effect when applied, for what that's worth. 

Don't really expect a fix on this one any time soon. Just keep forgetting to bug-report it in case someone smarter comes along.

data.title: Use fixed buffer size variable for allocating return buffer

milestone.description: This release is the first that the new Steering Committee will be responsible for. Our aims are to process as many existing outstanding issues/pull requests as possible and implement good practises for the future of the engine, such as automatic compile/unit testing of pull requests, as well as managing the different release files.

data.body:
Use fixed buffer size var when allocating return buffer from console.

This prevents issues when someone tries to use `sizeof(char* buffer)` and gives minor performance boost (comparing to usage of `dStrlen()`).
